sections.content:
The Congress finds that—
(1) The national debt is at a historically high level and poses a significant threat to the nation’s economic future.
(2) It is essential to address the national debt in order to ensure the long-term health of the economy and protect the interests of future generations.
(3) Increasing the debt limit is necessary to allow the government to meet its existing obligations.
sections.notes: This section outlines the legislative intent. It's common but emphasizes the urgency of addressing the debt.

sections.title: Debt Limit Increase
sections.content: The President is authorized to borrow an amount necessary to pay all obligations of the United States.
sections.notes: Standard debt ceiling increase provision.  Very concise and legally straightforward.

sections.title: Fiscal Year 2024 Spending Levels
sections.content:
Section 301 of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2023, is amended as follows:
(1) Paragraph (1) is redesignated as paragraph (2).
(2) A new paragraph (1) is added to read as follows: ‘Notwithstanding any other provision of law, for fiscal year 2024, the Secretary of Defense shall not request more than $886 billion in discretionary budget authority.’
sections.notes: This section directly modifies spending levels from a previous appropriations bill.  It’s a key element of the spending cuts.

sections.title: Medicare Provider Payments
sections.content:
Section 172(a)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended by striking subsection (4).
(5) The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall establish a process for determining the payment rates for Medicare providers, taking into account—
(1) The impact of the amendments made by this section on provider payments.
(2) The need to ensure that providers are adequately compensated for their services.
sections.notes: This section directly impacts Medicare provider payments. It's a significant change with potential consequences for healthcare delivery.

sections.title: IRS Tax Enforcement
sections.content: Section 304 of the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 is amended by adding the following at the end of subsection (c): ‘Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Secretary of the Treasury shall allocate not less than $81.3 billion to the Internal Revenue Service for the fiscal years ending September 30, 2024, and September 30, 2025, to enhance tax enforcement.'
sections.notes: This section reallocates funds from a previous law (the Inflation Reduction Act) to increase IRS enforcement.  It's a notable shift in priorities.

sections.title: Business Tax Provisions
sections.content:
Section 250(a) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended by striking paragraph (13).
(14) The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue guidance regarding the application of section 250 to—
(1) Payments made by a partnership or S corporation to its partners or shareholders for services rendered.
(2) Payments made by a C corporation to its shareholders for services rendered.
sections.notes: This section modifies business tax deductions. The addition of guidance from the Treasury Department is important – it clarifies how the change will be implemented.

sections.content: A corporate minimum tax shall be imposed on corporations with adjusted gross income exceeding $1 billion.

sections.content: This section outlines the legislative intent behind the bill. It includes findings about the importance of fiscal responsibility and a statement of purposes detailing the key goals of the legislation, such as suspending the debt ceiling, reducing spending, reforming entitlement programs, and implementing tax reforms.
sections.notes: Findings and statements of purpose are common in legislation but often provide context for the specific provisions within the bill. This section is particularly detailed, emphasizing the need for long-term economic stability.

sections.title: Provisions Relating to the Debt Limit
sections.content: This section suspends the debt ceiling until January 1, 2025. It essentially removes the immediate threat of a default by postponing the need to address the debt limit for an extended period.
sections.notes: The suspension of the debt ceiling is a central feature of the bill and represents a significant policy decision. The timing of the suspension (until 2025) is crucial.

sections.title: Fiscal Year 2024 Budget Reconciliation
sections.content: This section outlines the budget reconciliation process. It specifies the adjustments to be made to the budget authority and appropriations for fiscal year 2024, reflecting the spending cuts and reforms outlined in other sections of the bill.
sections.notes: Budget reconciliation is a legislative procedure used to pass legislation on budgetary matters with limited debate and amendment. This section details how those adjustments will be made.

sections.title: Tax Provisions
sections.content: This section includes tax provisions such as capping certain deductions and credits, increasing the income threshold for the child tax credit, and modifying the estate tax.
sections.notes: Tax provisions are often complex and subject to extensive debate. This section outlines specific changes to the tax code.

sections.title: Energy and Environmental Provisions
sections.content: This section includes provisions related to energy production, environmental regulations, and climate change. It addresses issues such as oil and gas leasing, methane emissions, and renewable energy development.
sections.notes: The inclusion of energy and environmental provisions demonstrates a broader approach to fiscal policy beyond just spending cuts and tax reform.

sections.title: Health Care Provisions
sections.content: This section includes provisions related to healthcare. It addresses issues such as Medicare eligibility, prescription drug costs, and health insurance coverage.
sections.notes: Healthcare is a significant area of federal spending, making these provisions particularly impactful.

sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to increase the debt limit by $1.5 trillion, subject to certain conditions.
sections.notes: This section addresses the critical issue of raising the debt ceiling. The 'certain conditions' are detailed in subsequent sections and relate to spending caps.

sections.title: Discretionary Spending Caps
sections.content: The President is directed to set discretionary spending levels for fiscal years 2024 through 2026, consistent with the budget resolution.
sections.notes: This section establishes spending limits on non-defense discretionary programs. The specific amounts are determined by the President and subject to congressional approval.

sections.content: The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is directed to make adjustments to mandatory spending programs, consistent with the budget resolution.
sections.notes: Similar to discretionary spending, this section limits spending on entitlement programs.

sections.title: Tax Provisions
sections.content: The bill includes provisions to extend certain tax credits and deductions, including the expanded child tax credit and the qualified business income deduction.
sections.notes: This section outlines specific tax changes. The details of these provisions are complex and require further examination.

sections.title: Increase to Debt Ceiling
sections.content: Section 3101(b) of title 31, United States Code, is increased by $4,000,000,000,000. This provision directly addresses the debt ceiling and provides a substantial increase in the amount of debt the U.S. government can issue.
sections.notes: This section is notable for its sheer magnitude – a $4 trillion increase. It’s a direct response to concerns about the federal debt and aims to provide sufficient headroom for future obligations.

sections.content: This Act may be cited as the "Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023".
sections.notes: Standard short title provision.  Clearly identifies the legislation's name for reference.

sections.title: Findings and Declarations
sections.content:
The Congress finds that:
(1) The Federal Government faces significant fiscal challenges due to rising debt levels and persistent deficits.
(2) It is essential to restore fiscal responsibility and ensure the long-term sustainability of the Federal budget.
(3) Reducing the federal deficit will promote economic growth and stability.
sections.notes: Standard findings/declarations section.  Sets the context for the legislation's purpose.

sections.title: General Directives
sections.content:
The President shall direct the Office of Management and Budget to:
(1) Develop a budget proposal for fiscal year 2024 that reflects the goals set forth in this Act.
(2) Provide regular updates to Congress on the implementation of this Act.
sections.notes: Standard directive to OMB.  Establishes an obligation for executive branch action.

sections.title: Revenue Provisions
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury shall take such actions as may be necessary to implement the revenue provisions of this Act.
sections.notes: Broad delegation of authority.  Common in reconciliation bills.

sections.title: Discretionary Expense Reductions
sections.content: The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall identify discretionary spending reductions that will result in a reduction in the federal deficit.
sections.notes: Core element of reconciliation.  Requires identifying specific cuts.

sections.title: Deficit Reduction Measures
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury shall take such actions as may be necessary to implement the deficit reduction measures of this Act.
sections.notes: Similar to section 104, a broad delegation.

sections.title: Payments for State and Local Government Use of Federal Funds
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury shall provide payments to state and local governments in accordance with section 302(b) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
sections.notes: Reference to a specific existing law.  This is a common mechanism for providing funds while adhering to deficit reduction targets.

sections.title: Other Provisions
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury shall take such actions as may be necessary to implement the other provisions of this Act.
sections.notes: Catch-all provision.  Often includes miscellaneous adjustments or clarifications.

sections.section_number: Section 3101(b) of title 31, United States Code
sections.title: Increase to the Budgetary Reserve Fund
sections.content: This section directly amends the Budgetary Reserve Fund established under Title 31. It mandates an increase of $4 trillion in this fund. The language is straightforward and legally precise, focusing on a numerical adjustment to a specific account.
sections.notes: The use of 'Notwithstanding any other provision' suggests a deliberate override of potentially conflicting regulations or existing statutory language regarding the Budgetary Reserve Fund.

sections.section_number: Section 3101(a) of title 31, United States Code
sections.title: Definition of the Budgetary Reserve Fund
sections.content: This section provides a definition for the Budgetary Reserve Fund. It's a standard provision to clarify the scope of the amendment and ensure consistent interpretation.
sections.notes: The inclusion of this definition is crucial for legal clarity, especially given the significant increase being made to the fund.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act may be cited as the ‘Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023’.
sections.notes: A standard short title provision.  It provides a concise name for the legislation.

sections.title: Findings and Purpose
sections.content:
The Congress finds that—
(1) The United States faces a significant fiscal challenge due to rising deficits and debt.
(2) Reducing the federal deficit is essential for ensuring long-term economic stability and prosperity.
(3)  A balanced approach is needed to address the fiscal challenges while protecting critical programs and services.
sections.notes: This section outlines the legislative intent. It's common but often includes specific findings relevant to the bill’s goals.

sections.title: Deficit Reduction Measures
sections.content:
The following measures are enacted to reduce the federal deficit:
(a) Spending Cuts: The President shall take action consistent with this Act to reduce discretionary spending by $1.5 trillion over ten years.
(b) Revenue Increases: The Secretary of the Treasury shall implement measures to increase revenue by $1.5 trillion over ten years.
sections.notes: This is a core section detailing the specific actions required to achieve deficit reduction.  The language is deliberately broad – ‘consistent with this Act’ allows for flexibility in implementation.

sections.title: Debt Limit Increase
sections.content: The debt limit shall be increased by $1.5 trillion, effective immediately.
sections.notes: A straightforward provision addressing the debt ceiling.  It's a common element in fiscal legislation.

sections.title: Implementation and Enforcement
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury shall implement the provisions of this Act and provide regular reports to Congress on progress toward achieving the deficit reduction targets.
sections.notes: This section establishes accountability.  It mandates reporting to Congress.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act may be cited as the 'Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023'.
sections.notes: Standard short title provision.

sections.title: Findings and Purpose
sections.content:
The Congress finds that—
(1) The national debt is at a historically high level, posing a significant threat to the economy.
(2) Reducing the deficit is essential to ensure long-term economic stability.
(3) The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 increased the national debt by approximately $480 billion.
(4) It is important to enact responsible fiscal policies that will reduce the deficit without harming economic growth.
sections.notes: Standard findings and purpose section.  The inclusion of specific reference to the Inflation Reduction Act highlights a key political context for this legislation.

sections.title: Deficit Reduction Measures
sections.content:
The Secretary of the Treasury shall take such actions as may be necessary to reduce the deficit by approximately $1.5 trillion over ten years, including—
(1) Implementing spending cuts across all federal agencies.
(2) Modifying existing programs to reduce costs.
(3) Adjusting tax rates and deductions.
sections.notes: This section is deliberately vague, relying on the Secretary of the Treasury's discretion. This is a common tactic in reconciliation bills to avoid specific mandates.

sections.title: Medicare Part D Adjustments
sections.content:
The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall—
(1) Increase the Medicare Part D beneficiary cost-sharing for prescription drugs.
(2) Reduce payments to providers under Medicaid clawback.
sections.notes: This section introduces specific changes to Medicare and Medicaid. The 'clawback' provision is a notable detail, indicating an attempt to control healthcare costs through provider reimbursement adjustments.

sections.title: Tax Provisions
sections.content:
The following tax provisions shall be repealed or modified—
(1) The expanded Child Tax Credit.
(2) The Bonus Depreciation deduction.
sections.notes: This section outlines specific tax changes.  The repeal of the expanded Child Tax Credit and the Bonus Depreciation are significant revenue-raising measures.

sections.title: Severability
sections.content: If any provision of this Act is held to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the other provisions of this Act.
sections.notes: Standard severability clause. Ensures that if one part of the bill is struck down, the rest remains in effect.

sections.title: Sunset Clause
sections.content: The provisions of this Act shall expire on December 31, 2025.
sections.notes: This is a sunset clause.  It means the bill's effects are temporary and will automatically end unless Congress acts to extend them.

sections.title: Debt Limit Increase
sections.content: Increases the national debt limit by $1.5 trillion over ten years. This is a key component of deficit reduction, allowing the government to meet its existing obligations without being constrained by the current debt ceiling.

sections.title: Discretionary Spending Caps
sections.content: Establishes spending caps on discretionary spending for fiscal years 2024 through 2026. These caps are significantly lower than the current levels, requiring difficult choices about which programs to maintain.

sections.title: IRS Tax Enforcement
sections.content: Increases funding for IRS tax enforcement by approximately $80 billion over ten years. This aims to improve tax compliance and increase revenue collection.

sections.title: Inflation Reduction Act Modifications
sections.content: Modifies certain provisions of the Inflation Reduction Act, primarily related to prescription drug pricing and energy tax credits. This is a significant change that could impact the effectiveness of those policies.

sections.title: Economic Adjustments
sections.content: Includes various economic adjustments, such as reducing the cost of federal student loan interest payments and modifying the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loan forgiveness rules. These adjustments are designed to offset some of the spending cuts.

sections.title: Budget Resolution
sections.content: This section outlines the budget resolution for fiscal year 2024, establishing spending levels and revenue targets. It essentially sets the framework within which the other provisions of the Act operate.
sections.notes: The budget resolution is a non-binding document that provides guidance to Congress on budgetary priorities.

sections.title: Debt Ceiling Increase
sections.content: This section increases the debt ceiling. It’s a standard provision in reconciliation bills designed to avoid default and maintain the government's ability to pay its obligations.
sections.notes: The increase is significant, reflecting the broader economic context and Congressional priorities.

sections.title: Discretionary Spending Reductions
sections.content: This section mandates reductions in discretionary spending across various federal agencies. The specific cuts are detailed elsewhere in the Act, but this section establishes the overall framework for these reductions.
sections.notes: The reductions are phased in over several years and target areas like defense, education, and housing.

sections.title: Tax Provisions
sections.content: This section outlines various tax provisions, including changes to the carried interest deduction and a limitation on state and local tax deductions. These provisions are designed to increase revenue.
sections.notes: The carried interest provision is particularly noteworthy as it represents a significant shift in tax policy.

sections.title: Payments for State and Local Governments
sections.content: This section provides payments to state and local governments. The amount is determined by the Act's revenue provisions.
sections.notes: These payments are intended to offset some of the spending cuts imposed on state and local entities.

sections.title: Debt Limit Extension – Temporary Suspension
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to collect payments toward the national debt limit until December 31, 2023.
sections.notes: This section provides a temporary suspension of the debt ceiling, preventing immediate default.

sections.title: Discretionary Spending Reductions – Non-Defense Discretionary Spending
sections.content: Beginning in fiscal year 2024, non-defense discretionary spending shall be reduced by $1.5 trillion over ten years.
sections.notes: This is a core element of the bill's deficit reduction strategy, targeting spending outside of defense.

sections.title: Discretionary Spending Reductions – Defense Discretionary Spending
sections.content: Beginning in fiscal year 2024, defense discretionary spending shall be reduced by $454 billion over ten years.
sections.notes: This section represents a significant cut to the military budget.

sections.title: Medicare Part D Benefit Reductions
sections.content: The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall reduce the rebates paid to pharmaceutical companies under section 267 of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Savings Act of 2003.
sections.notes: This aims to lower drug costs for beneficiaries by reducing manufacturer discounts.

sections.title: Payments for State and Local Government Retirees
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury shall make payments to state and local government retirees equal to the amount of any increase in their retirement benefits that occurs as a result of this Act.
sections.notes: This provision is intended to offset potential cuts to retiree benefits resulting from the spending reductions.

sections.title: Presidential Remission
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to reduce an obligation of the Federal Government by an amount equal to the amount of any increase in discretionary spending that occurs as a result of this Act.
sections.notes: This allows the President to use budgetary discretion to offset spending increases, providing flexibility for deficit reduction.

sections.title: Other Provisions
sections.content: The Secretary of Labor shall suspend certain regulations related to overtime pay.
sections.notes: This is a relatively minor provision aimed at reducing regulatory burdens.

sections.title: Debt Limit Increase
sections.content: Increases the debt limit by $4 trillion (approximately $4,000,000,000,000). This is a crucial element of the bill's fiscal responsibility goals. The language is straightforward and legally unambiguous – it simply states an increase to the existing debt ceiling.
sections.notes: This section relies heavily on the existing legal framework governing the debt limit.

sections.title: Discretionary Spending Reduction
sections.content: Directs agencies to reduce discretionary spending by approximately $1.5 trillion over a ten-year period. This section utilizes a broad directive, relying on the budgetary process and agency implementation to achieve the specified reduction. The exact mechanisms for achieving this reduction are not detailed within the bill itself.
sections.notes: The vagueness of this section is intentional, allowing flexibility in how agencies implement the spending cuts.

sections.title: Entitlement Spending Reduction
sections.content: Directs agencies to reduce entitlement spending by approximately $1.4 trillion over a ten-year period. Similar to section 102, this provision provides a general directive for reducing spending without specifying particular programs or cuts.
sections.notes: The lack of detail in this section is deliberate, aiming to avoid contentious debates about specific program reductions.

sections.title: Debt Ceiling Suspension
sections.content: This section suspends the application of the debt ceiling through February 16, 2025. This means that the federal government is authorized to borrow money up to its existing legal limit until that date.
sections.notes: This provision is crucial for avoiding a potential default on U.S. debt obligations.

sections.title: Spending Reductions
sections.content: This section establishes spending caps for discretionary and mandatory programs. It limits the growth of federal spending over a ten-year period, with specific reductions in various areas.
sections.notes: The spending caps are subject to certain exceptions and adjustments.

sections.title: Revenue Increases
sections.content: This section includes provisions for increasing federal revenue. It includes a tax increase on stock buybacks and a modification to the carried interest deduction.
sections.notes: These provisions are designed to generate additional revenue without raising marginal tax rates.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act may be cited as the ‘Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023’.
sections.notes: Standard short title provision.  Clearly identifies the legislation for reference.

sections.title: Recitals
sections.content:
The Congress makes the following findings:
(1) The federal government is currently facing a significant fiscal challenge, characterized by rising debt levels and persistent deficits.
(2) Reducing the federal deficit is essential to ensure long-term economic stability and prosperity.
(3) A balanced approach is needed that addresses both spending and revenue to achieve meaningful deficit reduction.
sections.notes: Recitals are common but this one explicitly frames the issue as a 'significant fiscal challenge' and emphasizes the need for a ‘balanced approach.’

sections.title: Deficit Reduction
sections.content: The President is directed to take all actions within the authority of the executive branch to reduce the federal deficit by at least $1.5 trillion over a ten-year period.
sections.notes: This section sets the overall goal for deficit reduction.  It's broad and relies on executive action – not specific legislative mandates.

sections.title: Spending Reductions
sections.content: The Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) shall issue guidance to federal agencies, consistent with existing laws and regulations, directing them to reduce discretionary spending by a specified amount over a ten-year period.
sections.notes: This section delegates authority to OMB to implement spending cuts. The specific amounts are not defined in the bill itself – this is where executive action will be crucial.

sections.title: Revenue Increases
sections.content: The Secretary of the Treasury shall take all actions within the authority of the executive branch to increase federal revenue by a specified amount over a ten-year period.
sections.notes: Similar to Section 4, this section delegates authority to the Treasury Department. The specific revenue increases are not defined in the bill itself.

sections.title: Debt Ceiling Suspension
sections.content: The debt ceiling shall not apply to the United States for a period of three years, commencing on January 1, 2025.
sections.notes: Standard debt ceiling suspension provision.  Provides certainty regarding the debt limit.

sections.title: Deficit Reduction
sections.content: This section increases the debt ceiling by $1.5 trillion over a ten-year period, subject to certain conditions, including the implementation of the discretionary spending caps outlined in Section 102.
sections.notes: This is the core provision addressing the immediate need for raising the debt ceiling. The 'subject to certain conditions' clause highlights the broader fiscal constraints imposed by the Act.

sections.title: Discretionary Spending Caps
sections.content: This section imposes caps on discretionary spending for fiscal years 2024 through 2026, limiting the growth of federal spending in various categories.
sections.notes: The use of 'discretionary spending caps' is a common feature of budget reconciliation legislation. It aims to control government expenditures by restricting funding for non-mandatory programs.

sections.title: Energy and Environmental Protection
sections.content: This section includes provisions related to fossil fuel production, renewable energy development, and environmental regulations. It specifically addresses the permitting process for oil and gas drilling on federal lands.
sections.notes: The inclusion of specific energy and environmental provisions is notable in a budget reconciliation bill, demonstrating a deliberate attempt to shape policy outcomes alongside deficit reduction.

sections.title: Healthcare Provisions
sections.content: This section addresses Medicare Part D prescription drug costs, Medicaid clawbacks, and other healthcare-related issues. It includes a provision to reduce the maximum rebate that pharmaceutical companies can provide to pharmacy benefit managers.
sections.notes: The inclusion of healthcare provisions is relatively common in budget reconciliation bills, as healthcare spending represents a significant portion of the federal budget.

sections.title: Tax Provisions
sections.content: This section modifies certain tax deductions and credits, including the child tax credit and the IRA deduction. It also includes a provision to increase the income threshold for eligibility for the student loan interest deduction.
sections.notes: Tax provisions are frequently included in budget reconciliation bills as they can have significant impacts on revenue collections.

sections.title: SECTION 1. RECONCILIATION
sections.content: This section establishes the reconciliation process for enacting the legislation. It states that the provisions of the bill are reconcilable under title II of House Concurrent Resolution 78, which outlines the procedures for reconciliation.
sections.notes: This is a standard reconciliation clause, common in budget-related legislation.  It essentially says this bill will be reconciled against existing budgetary rules.

sections.title: SECTION 2. DEFICIT REDUCTION MEASURES
sections.content: This section details the specific measures designed to reduce the deficit. It includes cuts to discretionary spending, increases in certain fees, and adjustments to tax credits.  The text lists numerous specific reductions across various government agencies.
sections.notes: This is a core section of any reconciliation bill. The specifics are highly detailed and represent significant policy changes.

sections.title: SECTION 3. PAYMENTS TO DEBT HOLDERS
sections.content: This section addresses the issue of potential debt payments to certain creditors if the debt limit is not raised. It outlines a process for determining whether such payments are necessary and how they would be made.
sections.notes: This provision is highly controversial and represents a significant departure from historical practice.  It's designed to avoid default but raises legal questions about the government’s obligations.

sections.title: SECTION 4. FEDERAL RESERVE ACT AMENDMENTS
sections.content: This section modifies the Federal Reserve Act to allow for greater flexibility in managing interest rates and other monetary policy tools.
sections.notes: These amendments are designed to give the Fed more latitude in responding to economic challenges.  They represent a shift in the government’s approach to monetary policy.

sections.title: SECTION 5. ENERGY SECURITY AND RENEWABLE ENERGY
sections.content: This section includes provisions related to energy security and renewable energy development.
sections.notes: The specific details of these provisions are outlined in the text, including incentives for renewable energy production and measures to reduce reliance on foreign oil.

sections.title: SECTION 6. AGRICULTURAL PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section contains provisions related to agricultural policy and support.
sections.notes: These provisions may include funding for agricultural research, conservation programs, and disaster assistance.

sections.title: SECTION 7. TRANSPORTATION PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section includes provisions related to transportation infrastructure and funding.
sections.notes: These provisions may include funding for highways, bridges, and public transit systems.

sections.title: SECTION 8. HOUSING PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section contains provisions related to housing assistance and affordability.
sections.notes: These provisions may include funding for affordable housing programs and rental assistance.

sections.title: SECTION 9. EDUCATIONAL PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section includes provisions related to education funding and initiatives.
sections.notes: These provisions may include funding for schools, colleges, and universities.

sections.title: SECTION 10. HEALTHCARE PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section contains provisions related to healthcare policy.
sections.notes: These provisions may include changes to Medicare and Medicaid programs.

sections.title: SECTION 11. CLIMATE CHANGE PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section includes provisions related to climate change mitigation and adaptation.
sections.notes: These provisions may include incentives for clean energy development and regulations on greenhouse gas emissions.

sections.title: SECTION 12. DEFENSE AUTHORIZATION REQUEST
sections.content: This section addresses the request for a defense authorization request.
sections.notes: This is a standard provision related to funding for national defense.

sections.title: SECTION 13. GENERAL DIRECTIVES
sections.content: This section includes general directives for various government agencies.
sections.notes: These directives provide guidance on how agencies should implement the provisions of the bill.

sections.title: SECTION 14. PAYMENTS TO STATES
sections.content: This section addresses potential payments to states due to sequestration or other factors.
sections.notes: This is a contingency provision designed to protect state funding during times of economic hardship.

sections.title: SECTION 15. SHORT CERTAININGS
sections.content: This section includes short certainings to clarify the scope and application of various provisions.
sections.notes: These provisions are used to avoid ambiguity and ensure that the bill is interpreted in a consistent manner.

sections.title: SHORT TITLE
sections.content: This Act is known as the 'Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023'.
sections.notes: The note indicates that the amount by which the total budget authority for fiscal year 2024 for the Department of Defense is reduced under section 251(a) of title X of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act Amendments of 1985 (31 U.S.C. 901 note), is increased by $4,000,000,000,000.

sections.title: Reconciliation
sections.content: This section provides for reconciliation pursuant to title II of H. Con. Res. 1, which establishes the procedures for enacting legislation that affects the federal budget.
sections.notes: The core function of this section is to establish the legal framework for using reconciliation – a legislative process allowing certain budgetary changes to bypass the standard filibuster rules in the Senate.

sections.title: Reconciliation
sections.content: This section establishes the reconciliation process for enacting the bill. It specifies that the bill is to be enacted through reconciliation pursuant to title II of House Concurrent Resolution 78, which allows Congress to pass legislation without a full Senate vote on certain budgetary matters.
sections.notes: The core of this section lies in its reliance on the Reconciliation Act of 2023. This is crucial because it bypasses the traditional filibuster rule in the Senate, allowing passage with a simple majority vote.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act may be cited as the 'Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023'.
sections.notes: The bill is a reconciliation measure, meaning it's designed to pass through Congress with only a simple majority vote in the Senate.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act is known as the Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023.

sections.notes: Common in legislation, but the specific wording here reflects the urgency of the situation. The emphasis on 'fiscal responsibility' is notable.

sections.title: Provisions Relating to the National Debt
sections.content: This section addresses the debt ceiling. It permanently increases the debt ceiling through 2024, subject to a concurrent resolution of approval.
sections.notes: A significant provision given the political context surrounding the debt limit. The 'concurrent resolution' is key – it requires agreement from both houses of Congress.

sections.title: Provisions Relating to Federal Spending
sections.content: This section outlines spending caps for fiscal years 2024 and 2025. It limits discretionary spending to the levels specified in the budget resolution.
sections.notes: The core of the legislation's fiscal impact. The reference to the 'budget resolution' is important – this bill is constrained by a pre-existing agreement.

sections.notes: These are relatively minor tax changes, but they demonstrate a broader effort to address various policy priorities.

sections.title: Provisions Relating to the Deficit Reduction
sections.content:
This is the core section of the bill. It's broken down into three subsections:
    A. **Non-Tax Revenue Measures:**  These include measures like extending sunset provisions on certain tax breaks and increasing IRS enforcement.
    B. **Tax Compliance Measures:** Primarily focuses on increased funding for the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to improve tax collection.
    C. **Spending Reductions:** Details specific cuts in discretionary spending across various government agencies, totaling approximately $1.5 trillion over ten years.
sections.notes: This section is highly detailed and represents the bulk of the bill's legislative impact.

sections.title: Provisions Relating to Government Operations
sections.content: This section addresses operational aspects of government, including adjustments to the debt ceiling process and suspension of certain sequestration requirements.
sections.notes: Addresses practical implementation details related to fiscal policy.

sections.title: Congressional Review Act Certification
sections.content: This section certifies that the bill complies with the requirements of the Congressional Review Act.
sections.notes: A standard procedural requirement ensuring legislative compliance.

sections.title: RECONCILIATION
sections.content: This section provides the legal basis for the reconciliation process used to pass this bill. It explicitly states that the Act is being enacted through the reconciliation procedure established under title II of the Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990.
sections.notes: This section is crucial as it bypasses the traditional filibuster in the Senate, allowing passage with a simple majority vote.

sections.title: ENERGY PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section outlines provisions related to energy production and conservation. It includes tax credits for renewable energy projects, investments in electric vehicle infrastructure, and support for energy efficiency programs.
sections.notes: These provisions are designed to accelerate the transition to a clean energy economy.

sections.title: HEALTHCARE PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section addresses healthcare costs. It includes provisions to lower prescription drug prices for seniors by allowing Medicare to negotiate drug prices and capping out-of-pocket expenses.
sections.notes: This is a significant change in Medicare policy.

sections.title: CLIMATE CHANGE PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section focuses on climate change mitigation. It includes investments in clean energy technologies, tax credits for carbon capture and storage projects, and funding for environmental justice initiatives.
sections.notes: The scale of investment is substantial, representing a significant commitment to combating climate change.

sections.title: TAX PROVISIONS
sections.content: This section details the tax changes included in the Act. It includes a 15% corporate minimum tax, increased taxes on multinational corporations, and an expansion of the Inflation Adjustment for Underpayments (IAU) penalty.
sections.notes: The 15% corporate minimum tax is a key element of the legislation's revenue-raising provisions.

sections.title: DEFICITS REDUCTION
sections.content: This section states that the Act is projected to reduce the federal deficit by $400 billion over 10 years.
sections.notes: The deficit reduction is achieved through a combination of tax increases and spending cuts.

sections.content: This section provides general directives to the executive branch regarding implementation of the Act's provisions.
sections.notes: These directives ensure that agencies have clear guidance on how to carry out the law.

sections.content: This Act may be cited as the 'Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023'.

sections.title: Findings and Purpose
sections.content: The Congress finds that: (1) the United States faces significant fiscal challenges, including rising debt levels and unsustainable long-term spending projections; (2) a balanced approach is necessary to address these challenges; and (3) the purpose of this Act is to reduce the deficit by approximately $1.5 trillion over ten years through a combination of spending cuts and revenue increases.
sections.notes: This section lays out the justification for the legislation – a common feature in reconciliation bills.

sections.title: Reconciliation Provisions
sections.content: This Act is enacted pursuant to title II of House Concurrent Resolution 76, the Balanced Budget and Economic Stability Act of 2022.
sections.notes: Crucially identifies this as a reconciliation bill.  It’s explicitly tied to a specific Congressional procedure (HCCR 76) which allows for bypassing the filibuster in the Senate.

sections.title: Fiscal Year 2024 Budget Resolution
sections.content: The budget resolution for fiscal year 2024 shall provide for: (1) discretionary spending limits consistent with the deficit reduction targets established by this Act; and (2) a cap on net federal debt.
sections.notes: Sets the overall budgetary framework.  The 'cap on net federal debt' is a key element – it’s not an outright ban but a limit that will require further action to maintain if spending exceeds revenue.
