sections.notes: This is a key provision aimed at increasing revenue from profitable companies.

sections.title: Tax Credits Extension
sections.content: This section amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend certain tax credits.
sections.notes: Includes extensions for renewable energy and electric vehicle tax credits.

sections.title: Clean Energy Tax Credit
sections.content: This section establishes a new tax credit for clean energy investments.
sections.notes: A significant provision focused on promoting renewable energy development.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act shall be known and cited as the ‘Inflation Reduction Act of 2022’.
sections.notes: Standard short title provision.

sections.title: Introduction & Purpose
sections.content: This section establishes the context for the reconciliation process, reiterating the authority granted by H.Con.Res. and outlining the overall goals of the effort. It typically includes a statement of intent regarding the specific budgetary outcomes sought.
sections.notes: Often contains a brief history of previous reconciliation efforts.

sections.title: Scope and Definitions
sections.content: This section defines key terms used throughout the document, such as ‘budget,’ ‘expenditure,’ ‘revenue,’ and ‘entitlement program.’ Precise definitions are crucial for ensuring consistent interpretation of the reconciliation provisions.
sections.notes: Definitions may be more detailed than those found in standard appropriations legislation.

sections.title: Reconciliation Provisions – Specific Amendments
sections.content: This is the core of the document. It lists each amendment subject to reconciliation, providing a detailed description of its impact on the budget and how it achieves the stated goals.  It will include specific dollar amounts and program names affected.
sections.notes: Amendments are often presented in a tabular format for clarity.

sections.title: Procedural Matters – Budgetary Considerations
sections.content: This section outlines the procedural rules governing the reconciliation process. It addresses issues such as voting procedures, time limits for consideration, and requirements for budget impact statements.
sections.notes: May include specific rules regarding quorum calls or expedited procedures.

sections.title: Severability, Sunset, and Effective Date
sections.content: This section addresses legal issues related to the reconciliation process. It includes a severability clause stating that if any provision of the document is found to be invalid, the remaining provisions will remain in effect.  It may also include a sunset clause specifying a date by which the reconciliation must be fully implemented or expire. Finally, it establishes the effective date of the reconciled legislation.
sections.notes: Sunset clauses are increasingly common in budget-related legislation and can create uncertainty about the long-term impact of the changes.

sections.title: Whereas Clause
sections.content: This section lays out a series of ‘whereas’ clauses, essentially stating the reasons for Congress's concern. It highlights the importance of sage-grouse conservation, acknowledges the BLM’s rule on sage-grouse conservation, and expresses concerns about its potential impact on federal lands, resource management, and economic activities.
sections.notes: This is a standard introductory element in resolutions, providing context for the legislative action.

sections.title: Findings and Declarations
sections.content: This section details the specific findings of Congress regarding the BLM rule. It asserts that the rule may have unintended consequences, potentially hindering economic development, restricting access to federal lands, and creating uncertainty for resource users.  It also states that a CRA review is warranted to ensure compliance with Congressional intent.
sections.notes: Findings are often included in legislation to establish a factual basis for the law's enactment. In this case, they frame the justification for the CRA review.

sections.title: Resolution
sections.content: This is the core of the resolution. It formally directs Congress to initiate a CRA review of the BLM’s sage-grouse rule.  It mandates that the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate conduct the review.
sections.notes: This section outlines the legislative action being taken – initiating the CRA review.

sections.title: Section 1. Congressional Review Act Review.
sections.content: This section explicitly invokes the Congressional Review Act (CRA). It states that Congress is directing an agency-wide review of the BLM rule, requiring the committees to analyze the rule's consistency with existing laws and regulations.  It also specifies the timeframe for completion – 60 legislative days.
sections.notes: This section is crucial as it’s where the CRA provisions are explicitly stated. The CRA allows Congress to review agency rules before they take effect, providing an opportunity to challenge them.

sections.title: Section 2. Scope of Review.
sections.content: This section defines the specific scope of the CRA review. It focuses on evaluating whether the BLM rule is consistent with existing federal laws, including those related to land use, resource management, and economic development.  It also directs the committees to consider potential impacts on various stakeholders, such as ranchers, energy companies, and conservation groups.
sections.notes: This section provides clarity regarding what aspects of the rule will be examined during the CRA review.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: This is a brief introductory section stating the intent of the resolution – to conduct a Congressional Review of the BLM’s proposed rule. It establishes the scope and purpose of the review.
sections.notes: Standard introductory language for CRRs.

sections.title: Findings and Declarations
sections.content: This section outlines the justifications for the review. It cites concerns about potential impacts on livestock grazing rights, water resources, and the BLM’s authority to manage public lands.  It specifically references the proposed rule's restrictions on stream crossings and argues that these restrictions may be inconsistent with Congressional intent regarding public land use.
sections.notes: This section is crucial in CRRs as it establishes the basis for the review. The language here is carefully worded to frame the issue within a broader debate about federal regulation of public lands.

sections.title: Resolution
sections.content: This is the core of the resolution. It formally directs Congress to conduct a review of the BLM’s proposed rule.  It mandates that the Government Accountability Office (GAO) be tasked with analyzing the rule and preparing a report summarizing its potential impacts. The resolution also requires the GAO to assess whether the rule is consistent with existing laws and regulations.
sections.notes: This section outlines the specific actions Congress must take. It’s a procedural mechanism for holding the executive branch accountable.

sections.title: Severability Clause
sections.content: This clause states that if any portion of the resolution is deemed invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions will remain in effect.  Standard language for most legislation.
sections.notes: A common provision ensuring the overall validity of the law.

sections.title: Sunset Clause
sections.content: This clause specifies that the Congressional Review Resolution will expire after a certain period (typically one year). This means the review process and any subsequent GAO report will automatically terminate unless Congress acts to extend it.
sections.notes: A sunset clause limits the duration of the legislation. It forces Congress to revisit the issue periodically.

sections.title: Effective Date
sections.content: This section states that the resolution becomes effective immediately upon its adoption by both houses of Congress.  It’s a standard provision for CRRs.
sections.notes: Ensures the review process begins promptly.

sections.title: Findings and Declarations
sections.content:
The Congress finds that:
	(a) Gun violence is a pervasive problem in the United States, resulting in countless deaths and injuries.
	(b) The victims of gun violence include not only those who have been killed but also their families, friends, and communities.
	(c) Recognizing the pain and suffering caused by gun violence is essential for promoting healing and preventing future tragedies.
sections.notes: This section lays out the foundational justification for the resolution. It’s a common feature of Congressional Resolutions, establishing the context and rationale behind the action.

sections.section_number: § 2. Designation of National Day of Remembrance.
sections.title: Designation of National Day of Remembrance
sections.content: The President is directed to issue a proclamation designating the first Sunday of each November as National Day of Remembrance for Victims of Gun Violence.
sections.notes: This is the core provision. It directs the executive branch (specifically, the President) to take action – issuing a proclamation – to formally recognize the day.

sections.title: Observance of National Day
sections.content: On National Day of Remembrance for Victims of Gun Violence, the President shall issue a proclamation directing all federal agencies to observe the day by displaying flags at half-staff and conducting activities that honor the memory of victims of gun violence.
sections.notes: This section details *how* the day should be observed. It’s a directive to federal agencies – a common element in legislation aiming for broad impact.

sections.title: Congressional Support
sections.content: Congress supports the observance of National Day of Remembrance for Victims of Gun Violence and encourages all Americans to participate in activities that honor the memory of victims of gun violence.
sections.notes: This section is a statement of congressional support. It’s less legally binding than the previous sections but serves as an endorsement.

sections.title: Preamble
sections.content: This preamble expresses the House of Representatives’ concern regarding the devastating impact of Hurricane Maria on Puerto Rico and its residents, emphasizing the need for a thorough investigation into the federal government's response to ensure accountability and prevent similar failures in future disasters.
sections.notes: Standard preamble language; sets the context and rationale for the resolution.

sections.title: Findings
sections.content: This section outlines a series of findings regarding the federal government’s response to Hurricane Maria. These include: 1) The inadequacy of pre-hurricane preparedness; 2) Logistical challenges in delivering aid; 3) Communication breakdowns between federal agencies and Puerto Rican authorities; 4) Insufficient distribution of essential supplies; 5) Lack of accountability for failures in the response.
sections.notes: These findings are crucial as they provide the basis for the committee’s investigation. They establish a specific narrative and highlight areas of concern.

sections.title: Establishment of the Select Committee
sections.content: This section details the establishment of a select committee specifically tasked with investigating the federal response. It includes: A) **Committee Name:** ‘Select Committee to Investigate the Federal Response to Hurricane Maria’; B) **Membership:** Specifies the number of members (15), including representatives from relevant committees (Armed Services, Transportation and Infrastructure, Natural Resources); C) **Powers and Duties:** Grants the committee broad investigative powers, including subpoena authority, access to documents and records, and the power to compel testimony; D) **Reporting Requirements:** Mandates the committee to submit a report of its findings and recommendations within a specified timeframe (one year).
sections.notes: This is the core section establishing the committee. The specific powers granted are significant, reflecting the seriousness of the investigation.

sections.title: Authority
sections.content: This section affirms the committee’s authority to exercise its powers and duties as outlined in Section III, referencing relevant statutes that grant investigative powers (e.g., Statutory Authority for Congressional Oversight). It also clarifies that the committee's actions are within the scope of its designated purpose.
sections.notes: Standard authority clause; reinforces the legal basis for the committee’s activities.

sections.title: Severability
sections.content: If any provision of this resolution is held to be invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect.
sections.notes: Standard severability clause; ensures that the resolution remains partially operative if one section is challenged legally.

sections.title: Sunset Clause
sections.content: This resolution shall expire one year from its enactment unless extended by subsequent legislation.
sections.notes: This is an uncommon provision for a Congressional Resolution. It limits the duration of the committee’s existence, forcing Congress to act if it wishes to continue the investigation beyond the initial year. This demonstrates a deliberate attempt to control spending and prevent indefinite investigations.

sections.title: Effective Date
sections.content: This resolution shall take effect immediately upon enactment.
sections.notes: Standard effective date clause; specifies when the resolution becomes law.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This resolution may be cited as the ‘Stream Crossing Review Act of 2023’.
sections.notes: Standard short title provision.  Simple and direct, clearly identifying the legislation's purpose for reference.

sections.title: Findings and Declarations
sections.content: The House of Representatives finds that: (1) The BLM’s proposed rule on stream crossings has the potential to significantly restrict access to water resources for ranchers and other landowners; (2) Restrictions on stream crossings could negatively impact livestock health, productivity, and economic viability; (3) Stream crossings are a traditional and essential component of ranching operations in many western states; and (4) The BLM’s rule lacks sufficient consideration of the potential impacts on these stakeholders.
sections.notes: This section lays out the rationale for the resolution. It's common to see ‘Findings’ sections in resolutions, but this one is particularly pointed, explicitly stating concerns about negative impacts on ranchers.  The language is deliberately emotive – 'potentially significantly restrict,' 'negatively impact livestock health and productivity.'

sections.title: Whereas Clause
sections.content: Whereas, the BLM has proposed a rule that would require landowners to obtain permits for stream crossings; and whereas, this requirement could impose significant costs and burdens on ranchers and other landowners; and whereas, the BLM’s proposal does not adequately consider alternative approaches to managing stream crossings; and whereas, many stream crossings are already established and have been used for decades without causing harm to water quality or aquatic ecosystems.
sections.notes: The ‘Whereas’ clause is a common feature of resolutions. It presents a series of statements (often assertions) that the resolution seeks to affirm.  Here, it highlights concerns about permitting requirements, cost burdens, lack of consideration of alternatives, and the historical use of stream crossings. The language is carefully chosen to frame the issue in a specific way.

sections.title: Resolution
sections.content: Resolved, that the Chair of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform shall direct the Committee’s staff to prepare a report analyzing the potential impacts of the BLM’s proposed rule on stream crossings on ranchers and other landowners in western states.
sections.notes: This is the core of the resolution. It directs specific action – preparing a report.  The language is deliberately focused on ‘potential impacts.’ This avoids committing the government to a particular outcome, which is typical for resolutions.

sections.title: Severability
sections.content: If any provision of this resolution is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the remaining provisions of this resolution.
sections.notes: Standard severability clause.  Ensures that if one part of the resolution is struck down by a court, the rest remains in effect. This is almost always included in resolutions.

sections.title: Findings and Declarations
sections.content: This resolution finds that the current situation at the southern border presents a significant challenge to national security, public safety, and humanitarian concerns. It declares the need for immediate action to address the processing of migrants and asylum seekers.
sections.notes: This section establishes the legislative intent and justification for the resolution.

sections.title: Expedited Processing of Asylum Claims
sections.content: The Secretary of Homeland Security shall implement a system to expedite the processing of asylum claims filed by migrants at the southern border. This includes establishing clear timelines for initial screenings, interviews, and decisions.
sections.notes: This section focuses on streamlining the asylum process.

sections.title: Supplemental Appropriations
sections.content: Congress authorizes an additional $X billion in supplemental appropriations to support border security efforts. These funds shall be allocated to the Department of Homeland Security, Border Patrol, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and Immigration Courts.
sections.notes: This section outlines the financial aspects of the resolution.

sections.title: Deployment of Technology
sections.content: The Secretary of Homeland Security shall deploy advanced technology, including drones and sensors, to enhance border surveillance and monitoring capabilities. This includes establishing protocols for data collection and analysis.
sections.notes: This section addresses the use of technological resources.

sections.title: Congressional Authority
sections.content: Congress asserts its constitutional authority over immigration enforcement at the southern border. This includes the power to oversee DHS and ICE operations and to ensure that federal laws are being properly implemented.
sections.notes: This section reaffirms congressional oversight.

sections.title: Sunset Clause
sections.content: The provisions of this resolution shall expire two years after its enactment unless reauthorized by Congress.
sections.notes: This clause limits the duration of the resolution's effects.

sections.title: Severability
sections.content: If any provision of this resolution is held to be invalid or unenforceable, such invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect the remaining provisions of the resolution.
sections.notes: This clause ensures that the rest of the resolution remains in effect if one part is challenged.

sections.title: Preamble
sections.content: Resolved by the House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, that it is the sense of the House that… (This section outlines the general intent and purpose of the resolution – acknowledging the driver shortage and its impact.)
sections.notes: The preamble sets the stage for the resolution. It’s often aspirational rather than legally binding.

sections.title: Findings
sections.content: Resolved that Congress finds that… (This section lists specific factual observations and conclusions related to the driver shortage. It’s based on data and reports, but doesn't create legal obligations.)
sections.notes: Findings are often used to justify the need for legislation. They provide context and support the rationale behind the resolution.

sections.title: Statement of Purpose
sections.content: Resolved that it is the purpose of this resolution to… (This section clearly states the goal of the resolution – establishing a task force and directing its work.)
sections.notes: The statement of purpose provides a concise summary of what the legislation aims to achieve.

sections.title: Establishment of the Task Force
sections.content: There is a section establishing a task force with specific authority and responsibilities. This will likely include details on how the task force is created, its duration, and its reporting structure.
sections.notes: This is a core section defining the entity being created.

sections.title: Task Force Membership
sections.content: Details on who will be part of the task force – including representatives from various agencies and stakeholders. This section may outline selection criteria and appointment procedures.
sections.notes: This defines the composition of the Task Force.

sections.title: Task Force Responsibilities
sections.content: A detailed list of what the task force is supposed to do – research, analyze data, hold hearings, develop recommendations, etc.
sections.notes: This section outlines the specific duties assigned to the Task Force.

sections.title: Reporting Requirements
sections.content: Specifies when and how the task force must report its findings and recommendations. This may include a timeline for interim reports and a final report.
sections.notes: This section dictates the reporting schedule.

sections.title: Funding
sections.content: Addresses how the task force will be funded. This may involve appropriations from specific accounts or a combination of federal and state funding.
sections.notes: This section deals with financial resources.

sections.title: Sunset Clause
sections.content: A provision stating that the resolution (or the task force's activities) will expire after a certain period. This prevents the resolution from becoming permanent.
sections.notes: This is an uncommon feature in resolutions, but it’s included to limit the scope and duration of the initiative.

sections.title: Statement of Congressional Intent
sections.content: Expresses the belief that AI has the potential to significantly benefit society but also poses risks that must be addressed proactively. Calls for a comprehensive and coordinated approach to AI governance.
sections.notes: This is standard language for ConRes, setting the stage for the subsequent provisions.

sections.title: Definitions
sections.content: Defines key terms related to AI, such as Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Algorithmic Bias.
sections.notes: Provides clarity on terminology used throughout the resolution.

sections.title: Foundational Principles
sections.content: Establishes core values for AI development and deployment, including human dignity, fairness, transparency, accountability, and safety.  Requires AI systems to align with these principles.
sections.notes: This section is relatively common in policy discussions but the explicit requirement of alignment is noteworthy.

sections.title: Research & Development Provisions
sections.content: Directs federal agencies (primarily NSF and DARPA) to prioritize research into AI safety, security, and ethical implications. Encourages collaboration between academia, industry, and government.
sections.notes: This section reflects a desire to foster innovation while mitigating potential risks.

sections.title: Workforce Development
sections.content: Mandates the development of training programs to prepare workers for jobs impacted by AI. Focuses on skills like data analysis, AI ethics, and human-machine interaction.
sections.notes: Recognizes the potential displacement caused by AI and seeks to address it through workforce retraining.

sections.title: Data Privacy & Security
sections.content: Calls for enhanced data privacy regulations specifically addressing AI applications. Emphasizes informed consent and minimizing data collection.
sections.notes: Addresses a critical concern regarding the use of personal data in AI systems.

sections.title: Ethical Considerations
sections.content: Establishes an interagency task force to develop ethical guidelines for AI development and deployment. Focuses on mitigating potential harms and promoting responsible innovation.
sections.notes: Highlights the importance of considering ethical implications beyond technical aspects.

sections.title: Regulatory Framework (Limited)
sections.content: Acknowledges the need for regulation but emphasizes a ‘light-touch’ approach, prioritizing voluntary standards and industry self-regulation. Directs agencies to monitor AI developments and assess potential risks.
sections.notes: This is a key distinction – it avoids prescriptive regulations and favors a flexible, adaptive approach.

sections.title: Sunset Clause & Review Process
sections.content: Specifies that the resolution expires after five years unless reauthorized by Congress. Mandates a comprehensive review of AI policies and recommendations within three years of expiration.
sections.notes: The sunset clause ensures ongoing scrutiny and prevents the resolution from becoming entrenched.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act may be cited as the ‘Modernizing Rural Broadband Access Act of 2025’.
sections.notes: Standard introductory section.  Clearly identifies the name of the legislation.

sections.title: Findings and Declarations
sections.content: The Congress finds that… (Lists a series of findings regarding the importance of broadband access for economic development, education, healthcare, and civic engagement in rural communities.  Includes statistics on current broadband availability and disparities.)
sections.notes: Common in legislation – provides justification for the bill's purpose. The specific findings are crucial to understanding the legislative intent.

sections.title: Definitions
sections.content: (Defines key terms used throughout the Act, such as ‘Broadband Provider,’ ‘Digital Divide,’ and ‘Eligible Provider.’  These definitions are critical for consistent interpretation of the law.)
sections.notes: Standard definition section. Precise definitions are vital to avoid ambiguity.

sections.title: Grant Program for Rural Broadband Expansion
sections.content: (Establishes a grant program administered by the USDA. Details eligibility criteria for providers, application process, funding amounts, and reporting requirements. Includes provisions for prioritizing projects that utilize innovative technologies.)
sections.notes: The core of the legislation – outlines how funds will be distributed.

sections.title: Infrastructure Investment Provisions
sections.content: (Requires the FCC to establish minimum performance standards for broadband service.  Specifies metrics such as speed, latency, and reliability. Includes provisions for ongoing monitoring and enforcement.)
sections.notes: Sets benchmarks for quality of service – important for ensuring that recipients are actually receiving adequate broadband.

sections.title: Regulatory Flexibility Provisions
sections.content: (Provides the USDA with authority to issue regulations and guidelines to administer the grant program.  Allows for adaptation to local conditions.)
sections.notes: Standard flexibility clause – allows for administrative adjustments.

sections.title: Sunset Clause
sections.content: (States that the provisions of this Act shall expire ten years after its enactment.  This limits the duration of the program.)
sections.notes: A ‘sunset clause’ – a common feature in legislation to ensure periodic review and reauthorization.

sections.title: Severability
sections.content: (States that if any provision of this Act is held to be invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect.)
sections.notes: Standard ‘severability’ clause – ensures that the law doesn't completely fail if one part is challenged.

sections.title: Effective Date
sections.content: (Specifies that this Act shall take effect sixty days after its enactment.)
sections.notes: Standard effective date provision.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This section establishes the short title of the Act as the ‘Rural Broadband Expansion and Digital Equity Act of 2025’.
sections.notes: Standard provision for identifying legislation.

sections.title: Findings and Purpose
sections.content: This section outlines the legislative basis, highlighting the importance of broadband access and the need to address the digital divide.
sections.notes: Common in many bills but emphasizes specific findings related to rural areas.

sections.title: Definitions
sections.content: This section defines key terms, ensuring consistent interpretation throughout the Act. Includes definitions for 'Broadband Service' and 'Digital Literacy'.
sections.notes: Essential for clarity and legal precision.

sections.title: Grant Programs
sections.content: This section details various grant programs designed to fund broadband infrastructure projects in rural areas. Includes funding categories such as ‘Infrastructure Grants’ and ‘Digital Literacy Grants’.
sections.notes: Core of the legislation, outlining how funds will be distributed.

sections.title: Infrastructure Development
sections.content: This section focuses on specific requirements for infrastructure projects, such as utilizing open-access networks and promoting competition among providers. Includes provisions related to mapping broadband availability.
sections.notes: Addresses technical aspects of deployment.

sections.title: Digital Literacy Initiatives
sections.content: This section outlines programs aimed at improving digital literacy skills in rural communities, including training for seniors and workforce development initiatives.
sections.notes: Recognizes the importance of skills alongside infrastructure.

sections.title: Regulatory Framework
sections.content: This section establishes a regulatory framework governing broadband providers operating in rural areas. Includes provisions related to data privacy and net neutrality.
sections.notes: Addresses potential conflicts between regulation and market forces.

sections.title: Sunset Provision
sections.content: This section includes a sunset provision, specifying that the Act’s funding will expire after 10 years unless reauthorized by Congress.
sections.notes: A common mechanism to ensure accountability and prevent long-term commitments.

sections.title: Severability
sections.content: This section states that if any provision of the Act is held invalid, the remaining provisions shall remain in effect.
sections.notes: Standard legal clause ensuring continuity.

sections.title: Effective Date
sections.content: This section specifies that the Act will take effect six months after its enactment.
sections.notes: Common provision determining when the law goes into effect.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act may be cited as the ‘Rural Broadband Expansion and Digital Equity Act of 2025’.
sections.notes: Standard short title provision.  Clearly identifies the legislation's name for reference.

sections.title: Findings and Purpose
sections.content: The Congress finds that… (Lists a series of findings regarding the digital divide and its impact). The purpose of this Act is to expand access to broadband internet service in rural areas, promote digital literacy, enhance cybersecurity, and support tribal broadband initiatives.
sections.notes: Standard 'Findings' section.  Provides the legislative basis for the bill.  The level of detail here is relatively high, explicitly stating the goals of the legislation.

sections.title: Definitions
sections.content: For the purposes of this Act, certain terms are defined as follows… (Defines key terms like ‘Broadband,’ ‘Digital Equity,’ and ‘Tribal Broadband.’)
sections.notes: Standard definitions section.  The inclusion of 'Digital Equity' is noteworthy – it demonstrates a broader understanding of the issue than simply access to speed.

sections.title: Grants for Broadband Deployment
sections.content: The Secretary of Commerce shall establish a grant program… (Details the grant structure, eligibility criteria, and funding amounts based on population density.)
sections.notes: This section is relatively standard in infrastructure legislation. The tiered grant system is a common approach to prioritize resources.

sections.title: Digital Literacy Programs
sections.content: Each state shall develop and implement a digital literacy program… (Mandates state-level programs with specific requirements regarding target populations.)
sections.notes: The requirement for *each* state to have a program is notable. It’s more proactive than simply offering funding.

sections.title: Cybersecurity Enhancements
sections.content: The Secretary of Homeland Security shall establish a cybersecurity task force… (Creates a dedicated task force with specific responsibilities and authority.)
sections.notes: This section is increasingly common in legislation addressing critical infrastructure. The inclusion of 'liability shielding' for compliant providers is a significant provision designed to incentivize participation.

sections.title: Tribal Broadband Initiatives
sections.content: The Secretary shall allocate at least 15% of the total grant funding… (Guarantees a specific percentage of funds for tribal broadband projects.)
sections.notes: This is an uncommon provision – dedicating a specific percentage to tribal initiatives demonstrates a commitment to addressing historical inequities in access.

sections.title: Regulatory Flexibility Provisions
sections.content: (This section provides flexibility for states and local governments to implement the Act's provisions in a manner consistent with existing regulations.)
sections.notes: Standard regulatory flexibility clause.  Allows for adaptation to varying state laws.

sections.title: Severability
sections.content: If any provision of this Act is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the remaining provisions of this Act.
sections.notes: Standard severability clause.  Ensures that valid parts of the law remain in effect if one section is challenged.

sections.title: Sunset Clause
sections.content: This Act shall expire ten (10) years after its enactment unless reauthorized by Congress.
sections.notes: Standard sunset clause.  Requires Congress to revisit the law after a set period – promotes ongoing evaluation and potential adjustments.

sections.title: Effective Date
sections.content: This Act shall take effect sixty (60) days after its enactment.
sections.notes: Standard effective date provision.  Provides a timeframe for implementation.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act is known as the ‘Modernization of Rural Broadband Access Act of 2025’.
sections.notes: Standard introductory section.  Provides a concise name for the legislation.

sections.title: Findings and Declarations
sections.content: The Congress finds that… (Lists numerous findings regarding the importance of broadband access, economic development, educational opportunities, healthcare delivery, and national security.  Includes specific statistics on rural broadband adoption rates.)
sections.notes: This section is common but often lengthy and detailed. It establishes the legislative intent.

sections.title: Definitions
sections.content: Defines key terms used throughout the Act, such as ‘Broadband Provider,’ ‘Digital Divide,’ and ‘Qualified Applicant.’  Includes specific technical definitions related to broadband speeds.
sections.notes: Standard definition section. The inclusion of 'technical standards' is noteworthy – it moves beyond simple conceptual definitions.

sections.title: Grant Program for Rural Broadband Expansion
sections.content: Establishes the ‘Rural Broadband Expansion Grant Program,’ outlining eligibility criteria, application procedures, grant amounts, and performance metrics.  Specifies a preference for innovative technologies.
sections.notes: This is the core of the legislation. The emphasis on 'innovative technologies' suggests a deliberate effort to move beyond traditional broadband deployment models.

sections.title: Infrastructure Investment Provisions
sections.content: Requires that all new broadband infrastructure deployed under the grant program meet specific technical standards (100 Mbps download/upload).  Mandates affordable service rates. Includes provisions for data privacy and cybersecurity.
sections.notes: The 100 Mbps minimum speed is a significant provision reflecting current expectations of internet performance. The inclusion of data privacy and cybersecurity regulations is relatively uncommon in rural broadband legislation – typically these are handled by separate agencies.

sections.title: Regulatory Flexibility Provisions
sections.content: Grants the FCC authority to establish rules regarding data privacy and cybersecurity for broadband providers participating in the grant program.  This section is designed to allow the FCC to adapt regulations to evolving technological landscapes.
sections.notes: Delegates regulatory power – a common feature of modern legislation.

sections.title: Sunset Clause
sections.content: The Rural Broadband Expansion Grant Program shall terminate five years after the date of enactment unless reauthorized by Congress.
sections.notes: A sunset clause limits the duration of a program.  This forces periodic review and potential reauthorization.

sections.title: Severability
sections.content: If any provision of this Act is held to be invalid or unenforceable, such invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect the remaining provisions of this Act.
sections.notes: Standard severability clause. Ensures that parts of the law remain in effect even if one section is challenged legally.

sections.title: Effective Date
sections.content: This Act shall take effect sixty days after the date of its enactment.
sections.notes: Standard effective date provision.  Provides a timeframe for implementation.

sections.title: Short Title
sections.content: This Act shall be known as the ‘Rural Broadband Expansion and Digital Equity Act of 2025’.
sections.notes: Standard short title provision. Provides a concise name for the legislation.

sections.title: Findings and Purpose
sections.content: The Congress finds that… (Lists numerous findings regarding the importance of broadband access for economic development, education, healthcare, and civic engagement). The purpose of this Act is to… (States the overall goals of expanding broadband access and promoting digital equity).
sections.notes: This section lays out the legislative rationale. It’s common but often lengthy and contains specific data points supporting the need for the legislation.

sections.title: Definitions
sections.content: Defines key terms used throughout the Act, including ‘Broadband Service Provider,’ ‘Digital Literacy,’ and ‘Underserved Area.’ The definitions are crucial for consistent interpretation.
sections.notes: Standard definition section. Precise definitions are vital to avoid ambiguity.

sections.title: Grant Programs
sections.content: Establishes several grant programs, including: (1) Infrastructure Development Grants – for building new broadband infrastructure; (2) Digital Literacy Grants – for providing digital literacy training; and (3) Technology Adoption Grants – to help low-income households purchase devices and internet service. Details eligibility criteria, application procedures, and funding amounts.
sections.notes: This is the core of the legislation. It outlines how funds will be distributed.

sections.title: Infrastructure Development
sections.content: Specifies requirements for infrastructure projects, including minimum broadband speeds and coverage areas. Includes provisions for prioritizing projects that utilize innovative technologies (e.g., satellite internet) and address geographic challenges.
sections.notes: Addresses technical standards and project criteria.

sections.title: Digital Literacy Initiatives
